HOPKINS RIFLEMEN MEET
PRINCETON AND COMPLETE 1 HIRD STAGE
Princeton Wins_ 498 to 490. Iowa
State Being Met This Week
in Intercollegiates
Princeton defeated Hopkins in
a rifle match for the week ending
February 23, by a score of 498 to
490. The shooting was done only
from the prone position, and only
the five highest scores counted.
The individual scores of the Hopkins team were as follows:
R. E. Parks, 100; G. M. Ruoff,
98; A. E. Thiessen,98; H. E. Wilgis, 97; W. M. Rowland, 97; J. E.
Mount, 95; F. E. Williams, 94; J.
D. Virdin, 94; F. T. Bates, 93;
and J. A. Cochran, 89. Total of
five highest, 490.

Engineering Levels Mountains
The Pack Train has become a relic of the
past, along with the Prairie Schooner.
Modern methods of transportation have
leveled mountains, brought San Francisco
nearer to New York, and widened the markets of all our great industries.
And the engineering brains and energy,
that have developed transportation to the
prominence it holds in the business of the
world today, are no longer employed in
improving means of overland travel alone.
Street Railways, Elevator Systems, Interurban Lines and Improved Shipping Lines—
these are some of the accomplishments of
engineering in the development of better
transportation.
Neither have the builders of such systems
been concerned only in the actual hauling of
people and materials. A study of the methods
of handling passengers and freight at the
large terminals has developed the Terminal
Engineer, who has greatly improved existing

ACHIEVEMENT

methods, and has developed entirely new
ones, as well.
Engineering, as it is applied to transportation, has had to concern itself with many
kinds of materials and many ways of handling
them under all manner of circumstances.
For instance the problems surrounding the
handling of iron ore, in bulk, are vastly
different from those encountered in moving
any one of the finished products manufactured from iron ore, that must also be
transported in large quantities. But Engineering constantly meets each situation with
improved transportation facilities.
Industry, as a whole, and the nations and
the people of the woad owe much to the
engineers, associate(i id' such large manufacturing industries as Westinghouse. They
have not only brought about vast improvements, but they have done so at a constantly
decreasing cost to those who derive the
greatest benefit from them.

INTERFRATERNITY SMOKER
COMMITTEE MEETS
A meeting of the fraternity
freshmen chosen to represent
•their various fraternities with reference to the arrangement of a
Freshman Smoker met in Room
113, Gilman Hall, at 12.30 P. M.
today. The- foilowing—m-en were
present: Alpha Kappa, Powell;
Pi Kappa Pi, Kidd; Silver Arrow,
Dunnbeller ; Kappa Sigma, Sandsbury; Omicron Kappa Omicron,
Pledge; Alpha Delta Phi, Hiss;
Delta Gamma Theta, Ningard ;
Pi Kappa Chi, Townsend; Beta
Theta Pi; Webster; Kappa Alpha, Holls ; Sigma Tau Delta,
Hudson; Phi Gamma Delta, Stick,
Delta Phi, Nelson.
Klinefelter, in behalf of the Interfraternity Board, explained the
method in which the smoker was
conducted last year, and told of
their mistakes, hoping that the
committee this year might profit
by them.
A meeting will be held today to
decide upon the night and the
time. At this meeting various
men will take charge of the different plans for the smoker.

Engineering Levels Mountains
The Pack Train has become a relic of the
past, along with the Prairie Schooner.
Modern methods of transportation have
leveled mountains, brought San Francisco
nearer to New York, and widened the markets of all our great industries.
And the engineering brains and energy,
that have developed transportation to the
prominence it holds in the business of the
world today, are no longer employed in
improving means of overland travel alone.
Street Railways, Elevator Systems, Interurban Lines and Improved Shipping Lines—
these are some of the accomplishments of
engineering in the development of better
transportation.
Neither have the builders of such systems
been concerned only in the actual hauling of
people and materials. A study of the methods
of handling passengers and freight at the
large terminals has developed the Terminal
Engineer, who has greatly improved existing

ACHIEVEMENT

methods, and has developed entirely new
ones, as well.
Engineering, as it is applied to transportation, has had to concern itself with many
kinds of materials and many ways of handling
them under all manner of circumstances.
For instance the problems surrounding the
handling of iron ore, in bulk, are vastly
different from those encountered in moving
any one of the finished products manufactured from iron ore, that must also be
transported in large quantities. But Engineering constantly meets each situation with
improved transportation facilities.
Industry, as a whole, and the nations and
the people of the woad owe much to the
engineers, associate(i id' such large manufacturing industries as Westinghouse. They
have not only brought about vast improvements, but they have done so at a constantly
decreasing cost to those who derive the
greatest benefit from them.
